												Might & Magic: Clash Of Heroes is a match 3 turn-based strategy R.P.G. developed by Capybara Games and published by Ubisoft. As an avid fan of all four of those genres, I have to say that I thoroughly enjoyed this gem of a title from start to finish. The game takes place in the beautifully crafted fantasy world of Ashan which has been a staple of all the Might & Magic titles released over the last couple of years. During a meeting between a group of powerful elven and human families of importance and nobility, the serene setting of this peaceful gathering is horribly interrupted by a suprise demon attack. Taken completely off-guard, the adults are swiftly overwhelmed and slaughtered but not before one of the mages quickly opens a portal whisping the families surviving children away from the deadly carnage. Though successful in it's execution, the magical portal is extremely unstable and sends each of the five kids to a different part of Ashan and this unfortunate series of events is what sets the stage for the fascinating story of Might & Magic: Clash Of Heroes. Down but definitely not out, you take control of five of the childhood heroes Anwen, Godric, Fiona, Aidan and Nadia. Scattered across five different regions of Ashan, the heroes must travel their own dangerous paths to grow in strength, unravel a demonic plot, and ultimately save the world from Chaos.Unlike other Might & Magic titles, the battles in this game take place in match 3 turn-based format. Each hero can command an army with up to five different types of units. Each unit comes in a variety of different colors and in order to charge them up for battle you must match three units of the same color. This may sound easy enough but like the old saying goes..."Easy to learn...hard to master.". Once charged, your unit will execute it's particular method of attack against your opponent with the goal being to defeat your enemy before they in turn defeat you. Besides the fun match 3 play, there is also a heavy element of strategy involved as you decide which soldiers on the battlefield to send into attack and which to sacrifice for the greater good. You also have the chance to increase the potency of your attacks through a method called "linking". This is done by matching multiple groups of units of the same color laterally on the battlefield instantly providing an immediate boost to their attack power. Like with any particular R.P.G. worth it's salt, you of course earn experience points as you win battles and complete challenges thus allowing your hero to level up. Also besides the regular battles, you will face challenging boss fights, have the opportunity to take optional sidequests to complete bounties and solve a number of highly complex yet extremely fun puzzle battles that task you with finding the right combination of moves to solve them. I'm definitely not a very smart person but I have to say that some of those puzzle battles were very very tough to solve but the satisfaction that you received after finally completing them was well worth the frustration and time spent. There is also loot to be acquired in the form of various artifacts and trinkets that you receive either through exploration, defeating foes or by completing tasks. These items will provide your hero with new abilities that will greatly help you on the battlefield. Graphically, Might & Magic: Clash Of Heroes is a gorgeous game to behold. The cutscene artwork has a beautiful manga-inspired look to it that is just a joy to watch as the story unfolds. The various regions of Ashan that you traverse during the course of the game are vibrantly detailed and each area has a unique look and culture of it's own. From the majestic woodelves of heavily forested Irollan, to the elite knights of the Holy Griffon Empire and the arcane necromancers of Heresh and beyond...you definitely will not feel like you've visited the same place twice with this title. The battlefields have a wonderful visual style to them as well but the pinnacle of the graphics in this game would without a doubt be the units themselves. They are just so wonderfully stylized and animated to the point where it looks less like a videogame and more like a cartoon or anime....they are indeed that beautiful. It becomes a treat to watch them initiate their attacks after charging them up just to see what they will do. The music and sound effects also do a fine job of capturing intense moments during the story and battles as well as adding to the variety of the different environments that you visit throughout Ashan. All of this is wonderfully presented in full HD as well.To summarize, I was very shocked at how great this game was when I first started playing it because I had always assumed that the Puzzle Quest series, which I adore, was the pinnacle of match 3 puzzle based R.P.G.'s...until now. To me this title definitely gives Puzzle Quest a run for the money in those genres and I would love to see other Might & Magic match 3 titles like this one yet sadly it seems as though that may never happen. There have been other Might & Magic games released since this one but they have all returned to the tried and true formula of turn based strategy minus the match 3 of this particular title. Despite that, I really enjoyed this game and will continue to play for years to come and would highly recommend this title to any fan of match 3, puzzle, strategy, R.P.G. or any combination of the four. Might & Magic: Clash Of Heroes is a title that any Steam user would be proud to have in their library.

												This is a nifty little title that blends together Match-3 dynamics with a tactical combat layer.  You form columns of like-colored creatures to form an attack or rows of like-colored creatures to create a wall. 												This is a good, but oddly overlooked puzzle fighter. Beyond the basic rules of putting three units of the same colour in a line to launch an attack or build defensive walls, there's a decent amount of strategy involved. Each of the 40-odd units in the game has a different attack power, special ability, and takes a different amount of time to prepare their attack - during which your opponent can try to defend or counter it. You can also power up your attacks by setting them to launch on the same turn or stacking one right on top of another. And of course, this wouldn't be a Heroes game if you weren't playing a hero, with their own, potentially game-changing ability.The single-player campaign is quite long, and offers a mild progression and resource management element (as in, you'll have to buy special units if you get them killed in combat) in addition to unique boss encounters. There's also a story, of course, somehow related to Heroes 5, but cartoony so kids might like it, maybe? I don't know, I've lost interest in HoMM around 3, and in cartoons around 12.The multiplayer component works reasonably well, but you'll have to provide your own opponents - bring a friend or two. And the DLC allows you to play not just as one of the heroes from the campaign, but also the bosses, who can function quite differently.So, if you're at all into puzzle fighters, give this one a go. It's good, even if you just play the campaign. Maybe play a round or two against your friends.

, 2015
												Verdict: This one was a surprise. A beautiful, polished game with excellent presentation, surprising strategic depth and a simple but engaging story. The best Heroes of Might and Magic game for quite some time. 8/10Story: The story is simple and light but, married with the clean presentation, is still an endearing and somewhat engaging experience. Straightforward but nevertheless interesting characters will appeal to most people, and the big names to Heroes fans in particular. 6/10Gameplay:  I should start this by saying that I hate Match 3 games with a burning passion. But it feels wrong to even call this Match 3; it feels more like genuine turn-based strategy. Each side takes turns moving units around to match three and create ‘formations’, which then attack the other side. This is simple at first but, as you unlock new units and combinations, it becomes much more complex and interesting. It’s a very well-balanced game with offensive, defensive and mixed strategies all being equally viable. 9/10Graphics: The presentation is excellent, colourful and polished, and the attack animations are powerful. It’s surprisingly fun to see classic Heroes characters rendered in an anime style. 8/10Sound/Music: The sound is great and the re-mastered soundtrack will cause Heroes fans to reminisce like crazy.  8/10

												I feel that this game is deceptively underrated.If you ever wanted a puzzle-strategy-RPG-type game (think: like Puzzle Quest), this is the one to go for. The mechanics are very well-designed, the in-game assets and UI look great at any resolution, and the single-player content will likely be satisfying until completion. Being able to kick-back with a 360 controller is also a plus.Despite being a genre hybrid and having RNG, strategy and tactics actually plays a significant role, as you can customize your unit/hero/item loadout before every game, and can try-out different things once on the field. For example, you could use units/heroes that are quick to charge-up, and have them all constantly bombard your opponent from multiple points, making it difficult to defend against. Or you could focus on using strong hero units (which a player has a limited number of) that take a while to charge, but have a lot of damage-output once its turn comes and if it hasn't taken too much damage from your opponent before then. Or just about any loadout combination and tactics you can think-up.The game also uses high-resolution art assets and an automatically-scaling UI, so the game will look great at any resolution. And the unit animations themselves (especially the Hero attack animations) are both well-done and expressive, but won't make the field difficult to grok at any point. I run the game at 1440p without any issues.As far as the single-player mode, I thought it was well-done. While the story and characters are kind-of garbage, and I didn't like starting a new character for each chapter, the game's difficulty sloped-up very satisfyingly, and every boss was a novelty that forced you to change your tactics. I believe the reason for this is because of each character's level-cap, where the later bosses/mini-bosses in each area were all crafted for you to be at that cap, so that you couldn't just grind your way out for an easy victory against them. Aside from the bit-too-easy battles at the start and the huge difficulty ramp at the final boss, the single-player was satisfying and challenging enough to pull me the entire way through.If you've been looking for a puzzle-RPG hybrid and want a chill game to kick back with, I'd recommend M&M: CoH. Just bring a controller.

												This game is quite fun in some places, and excruciatingly painful in some missions.  Pluses: Battle puzzles in which you have 1 turn to defeat all enemies on the board. Really makes you think about how to set up combination moves.Minuses: Certain missions in the single player campaign simply come down to luck. You can have the best strategy in the world, but you are under a severe time constraint in some missions, and if the initial setup is bad, then you might as well just reset the mission and try for a new initial setup. (Which, thankfully is possible by "retreat" option from menu. Though it costs a bit of resources in some missions)As far as gameplay, it's match 3, which various bonuses for fusing units, chaining units, gaining extra moves for multi-combo plays. Pretty simple, and yet there is a bit of strategy to try and squeeze the most from your units with the least amount of moves.Various "Artifacts" also affect the gameplay, and choosing the right artifacts and unit combinations can make or break certain fights.All in all, an acceptable fun, slightly casual, with a few hair pulling moments game which kept me busy for several days.If the price is acceptable in your eyes, I'd give it a solid 7/10 buy.

												Might & Magic: Clash of Heroes is a turn-based pvp puzzle game.  It is nothing like the M&M series, outside of the fact that you have some familiar monster names.  You set up three of a kind vertical to attack, and three of a kind horizontal to defend.  The turn-based aspect limits how many moves you have per turn, so every action has severe consequences.  There is a bit of luck involved when requesting more pieces, and expect to get frusturated from time to time where luck can sometimes overthrow the best strategist.  Developing combos is a must for advancing in the game.  The AI will be relentless, so make sure to never hold back.As a person who loves puzzle/strategy games, this was really up my alley.  If you aren't a puzzle enthusiast, you might find it a little overwhelming, as there are no random encounters to build up the level of your heroes and armies.  There are optional encounters to help build up your level, but every battle win helps build up the levels of your units.

												This is a smartphone game. Everything about it screams "smartphone port". The UI is clunky and ugly, although the artstyle is nice. Everything about it is designed to be operated with a big fat thumb, one handed on the toilet. Except.. the match length... the average match took me about 30 to 45 minutes to complete, all credit due to the RNG.Matches are won by sheer luck where your and the opponents reinforcements end up. If you are lucky, they will be opportune and you can get ahead with your 3 moves, if you are not... well then the opponent will stack up on walls, making it impossible to get units through. At this point you end up chipping away with minimal damage at the enemy, praying your big beefy units make it through, because the match is dragging on and on. Each match i won, was a stalmate until RNGesus finally decided to create an opening for me by giving the opponent an inopportune reinforcement draw.There is no way to react to the loadout of the enemy, other than save scumming, and with 3 moves there was no way to make big sweeping changes to the positioning. You are focused on using whatever RNG gives you, than wasting time trying to set up big attacks. Why? Because the AI is constantly combining whatever it can.. which forces the player to do the same, trying to ward off the attacks long enough until there is an opening created by RNG.But what really makes me not recommend the game... are some of the story encounters, where the game isn't just content with forcing you to somehow beat an enemy. No, the game throws objectives in the encounter at you. RNG moving 'allies' in the enemy ranks, which you aren't supposed to hit. Or having to protect a unit. Or hit two target at the very same time. All the while the AI is playing as it always does... basically handicapping the player.There is an interesting formation and fusion system in the game, but under the constant onslaught of the AI pulling one off is more luck than skill. And i can only imagine that playing against real players you either have a chess game or someone is playing like the AI, combining whatever they can and thus forcing you to do the same.Its a shame. It has a pretty artwork and it could have been a really nice game, if it either let you decide where your reinforcement went, or gave you more than 3 moves, so you could actually make changes to your rows. So, its 90% luck and 10% skill.

												I want to recommend this game, I really do. But I cannot, here are some thoughts on this game. In short, the PC version is the avatar of Ubisoft's recent approach on the M&M franchise which is to gut out any magic of the game and butcher anything that is creative.I have played the NDS version of this game for more than 200 hours. When compared to the NDS version, the only thing improves on the PC is the graphics. Game mechanics wise, the game is completely gutted and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ised. In the NDS version, there are many interesting creature abilities, and many interesting faction specific artefacts which can boost these abilities even more. When these two combines, there are so many tatics to explore and so much fun to enjoy. Now they are completely gone. Just to name a few, druid from Sylvan is now trash with his ability shortened by one round and his artefact gutted. This unit is now a joke. Maybe still usable, but no longer fun to beat an opponent who is stronger than you. Djinn suffered the same fate, artefact gutted and ability itself neutered. Rashasa is a mediocre Champion, but with his artefact on the NDS, which gives him 25% PWR boost and 1 round charge reduction, he becomes an formiddable foe. On PC? sorry it is spayed and the Rakshasa's artefact now is a joke. Rashasa also received an PWR punish and now this unit looks like a joke. There are many more, I won't cover them in detail. Anyone who enjoyed the NDS version will know this better.It may seem to stem from the balancing point of view, but this game is basically dead online, and you would probably only play with your friends. And if that is the case, the NDS version with more fun is clearly a superior choice. Instead of fixing some of the weaker units/artefacts/heroes on the NDS, the developer decided to gut anything that is outstandingly fun and watch this game burn.

												This is a fine example of branding gone horribly wrong.  Like taking a brand that is a good, cozy brand that you grew up with and has always been a friend and a mark of reliable quality, a brand of trust, and doing something bizarre with it.   Like if Campbells Soup went into manufacturing diesel motors.   Even if the motors they make are good, they shouldn't do it.  Stahp. We all know Might and Magic as the franchise of addictive 4X games with simplistic tactical combat, classical fantasy units like orcs, knights, vampires and dragons.  Build your cities and outposts, capture resources, cast magic spells and win!Not with this game.  They put Legend of Zelda, a teenaged american nerd who thinks he can draw anime, tetris and plants vs zombies into a blender, crushed what came out and stamped "Might and Magic: No Really!" on it.    It's a weak puzzle game with a strange anime type veneer on the front.  They threw away all the classical features of Might and Magic, leaving a poor competitor to Bejewlled in place. Graphics: Limited but works okay in 4K.  Artwork is "american anime", which doesn't work with Might & Magic.  There should be none of this kind of thing. Gameplay:  Very bad.   You go in expecting you're playing Might & Magic and you're playing plants vs Zombies turned 90 degrees.   You dump your soldiers randomly onto the field like a game of tetris, then build them into stacks or rows so they can do something.   Thematically it's weird.  In terms of gameplay it just doesn't make any sense.Technical: Not really a 3D game.  Stable and functional, but very simplistic. Might & Magic is a good solid franchise.  It's not the best and far from the worst.  This game might even be worth a recommendation but the failed branding and sense of betrayal, combined with being far, far below par for a game in this franchise, with such weak gameplay, leaves me with no choice but the thumbs down.   There are better Might & Magic games. There are better puzzle games.  This one has no place to go but down, like pizza flavoured beer, some combinations just don't work.

												A pretty simplistic game in appearance that reveals its complexity through a single hour of playtime.The basic 3-units principle(to make an attack, three vertical units of the same colour, to make walls, three horizontal) gets immensely complex and varied once you add links(having groups of the same colour attack at the same turn) that reinforce your attack, fusions(two attack groups one behind the other fuse into one group twice as strong), and of course Elite and Champion units that require 2 and 4 units to activate them.Almost every single unit from every single race has a specific capacity, poison, jumping over walls, magical defenses, immunity to attack while charging, hacking the enemy lines/enemy charging power while charging, the variety added to the basic 3-units system makes this an incredibly capable game with possibilities that never seem to be insufficient no matter the circumstances. You can literally be about to be killed by your enemy, call reinforcements, and find yourself gifted with a generous unit placement that allows you to build the walls and defenses you need to just survive and counterattack to victory. There is a freshness in this game that never dies out.It's actually one of its greatest strengths and weaknesses, how random the battles can go. You can be gifted with a perfect line of units from the very start or have absolutely nothing to go on with. The game can be very frustrating when a perfectly planned attack is ruined by the sudden arrival of an enemy Champion just in the column you're about to use to finish off your foe. It can also be frustrating in the other way: you will call reinforcements to see one of your costly Champion units die immediately at the hands of some basic enemy attack with 2 attack because you couldn't get it moving in time.As frustrating and unfair as the randomness is, it is also one of this game's best aspects. The only reason I speedrun this game is that it has the merit of never(apart from the tutorials) making me feel like déjà vu. Every battle is at least new enough, no moments in the game feel like I've been here before(except the bosses, of which there are only 4, along with quite a few unfair pre-prepared battles) and even when it does happen, the randomness of the reinforcements usually palliates that very quickly.Gameplay-wise, it's simply excellent. Having played through the campaign quite a few times for speedrunning, I have yet to find this game to bore me at any point, and it's quite surprising to realise how a simple system can be at the same time constantly demanding and very free.A good example is the fusions: if you want one, with core, Elite or Champion units, you're gonna have to get rid of all your walls first, since you need six tiles to make any fusion and there are only six between the goal your enemy has to hit and your first line.Beyond that, every hero has got his own superpower which can range from somewhat poor(hello Cyrus) to ridiculously broken when you know how to use them(hello Aidan with lots of walls, Anwen with a clear opening, Markal with two uncharged Death Knights).Beyond beyond that, artifacts can be found in many flavors in the campaign and then used profusely in skirmishes or online battles. And the variety there is by no means inferior to the one in the units, although I'm sure everyone will end up using ridiculously strong artifacts like the Spider Cloak, Lion's Mane or Celerity Ring.On a side note, the balancing of the campaigns is a bit poor. Why is Nadia not only ridiculously rich in HP(she starts at level 7 out of 10!), but also given enemies that play defensively, troops that make almost no damage, and is also generously dotted with Academy enemies, who can raise layers of superwalls like drinking a cup of coffee? It makes her campaign ridiculously long and just unpleasant. The times I get for Anwen range under 50 minutes, Godric takes less than an hour, Fiona has a rather long campaign that takes about 1h10 minutes, Aidan has a rather short campaign that also takes less than an hour, and Nadia ends up taking me 1 hour 40 minutes!Continuing on the bad side, the story is completely ignorable. It's not bad(no big plot holes, awful writing or terrible characters) but absolutely nothing about it feels in any way original. The characters almost feel stereotypical, you have the courageous and honorable big brother, the courageous but more sheltered little sister, the more angsty teenage younger brother, the huntress of the woods, the good student girl who fights the good fight...All of their personalities can be written in a quick line and although they never made me facepalm(none of the main five anyway), the last thing I wanted was to be tasked with finding an interesting personality trait among them. I don't mind finding needles in haystacks, but this is just impossible.The story is of the same type, it's nothing awful, but it doesn't convey anything even remotely amusing or deep. It ends in a happy note that works but doesn't really follow the somewhat tragic storytelling we had for most of the game. It's not really light on clichés and nothing about it is worth mentioning. I had a laugh once in the entire game. A giggle, really, at the demon who dies from the volcanic eruption he wanted to see. The rest is skippable. Special mention, though, to the villains: they range from comic relief(Azexes and his forgetful schoolboy behavior) to so obvious it hurts(Carlyle and his fashion for being a general ♥♥♥♥).Visually, I like the animé art style quite a lot, and the quality of the animations is certainly very helpful at making it a nice game to watch. I do have a serious issue about those: they're long. REALLY long. Sometimes it's ok, but seeing the knight twirl his spear around before charging for the 1000th time has really grown old. Less long animations would've really helped in making the game a lot more fun. The PLAYER TURN and ENEMY TURN screens are also ridiculous, they last something like 3,5 seconds! Talk about a needless loss of time! Those could've simply not existed and all would've been better. As much as I appreciate the animé visual style for almost everyone, some races are totally failed: the good guys and necromancers are mostly fine, but the magicians' golems or titans look nothing like the machines they are, although that's nothing in comparison to the Demons and how every unit but the hound is failed. Even when lit with flames and about to strike, I find it difficult to take the immense Pit Fiend more seriously than a plushie. Demons look neither scary nor ugly, and that's a true minus for me.With all that said, the last element is the music.It sucks.No other way to say it. This game has very poor music.Out of five campaigns, forests, a capital city of men, the land of the undead, Hell, and a mighty Magician tower, I remember exactly zero theme songs. Why? Because there aren't any songs. It's all ambients. BAD ambients, with no memorable sounds at all. Whooshing winds and shaking leaves, that's all. The battle musics are thankfully very varied, however that would be a good thing only if they didn't all suck as well! Out of the eight or so battle themes, there is one I like. The final boss music is fine too. The victory theme(the first 4 seconds of it anyway) and the two former are the only songs I can say I appreciate musically out of the whole game. Having played HoMM5 before, I know that many of these songs were taken from the rest of the franchise and sort of put in this one. It doesn't fit, none of the songs are that good, so it's a game that is terribly uninteresting musically.A lot more could be said about bad minigames, Sonic 06-type loading times(two loading times into each battle), but I reached the limit.Final word is that despite my complaints, this is an incredibly fun and varied game that always develops into more complexity and fun. Try it.

												It may not look like much compared to any games in the Might&Magic series, however there is more than this game than it's cover lets on. While staying impressively true to the Might&Magic universe, it brings a lighter mood to the usually serious Might&Magic games. Even in it's "combat" you can see many similarities to past games of the series. Though don't be confused, this game is much different. It is more strategic than anything, and often requires you to think about your moves rather than just throwing units at the enemy. It is probably one of the most relaxed, fun, and challenging strategy games I have ever played. Not to mention the availability of co-op online gameplay, which brings in even more strategy than with just one-on-one gameplay.There aren't many cons I can think of off the top of my head. If anything, it would be the role luck plays in many of the games. Sometimes you just get delt a bad hand, and that can ruin the whole game. Even with the Relics you get from playing the campagin, they often aren't enough to save you from a bad start. Or sometimes the enemy start is just so good, you can't come back from his initial moves.Even so, this game is great. Whether you're into hardcore strategy or just enjoy a relaxed strategy, this game might be for you. While you can play hardcore and think 5 billion moves ahead of the other player(s) you can also just think one or two moves ahead,and still have fun, maybe even win! This is a great game, no matter what side of gaming you come from!

												Ever since Ubisoft picked up the rights to the Might & Magic franchise after 3DO went bankrupt and took New World Computing down with it, their work as a publisher for the franchise has been...hit or miss. And usually a buggy, ill provided mess. Clash of Heroes is not such a story; it is the single most polished game to come out of the franchise since the aquisition, helped by its gorgeous art style that immediately evokes Avatar: The Last Airbender, but actually makes me think back to Heroes of Might & Magic 2, with its simple graphics still being the best in the franchise due to just a timeless style. The only thing holding Clash of Heroes back from being an out and out classic is its schizophrenic difficulty curve, and an ending sequence barely any better than a series of title cards with plain letter text.But it's an incredibly solid puzzle game, and, while the unit recruiting/resource mechanic is a bit tacked on, the artifact and unit tier mechanics are definitely good additions. And, god damn, what sells this game the most, for me, is the total tongue in cheek nature of its story and characters. Like, after Heroes V took itself way too seriously and was just frustratingly stupid, and Dark Messiah took itself way too seriously and was just hilariously stupid, Clash of Heroes almost went and took the ♥♥♥♥ out of the Ashan universe, which, coupled with Might & Magic X's actually good storyline, gave me hope for this revival of the franchise.

												Clash of Heroes follows the story of five young adults from different cultures that come together to stop a demon invasion. Clash of Heroes is able to find that perfect level where everything is customizable enough that the game doesn't become oversimplified and dreary, but also keeps it simple enough so that we don't get overwhelmed. Each one of the five factions has its own distinct style, and even though the smooth animations and environments are remarkably detailed, they fit just perfectly and never detract from the gameplay. Although the basic foundations of battle are simple and easy to understand, many factors have to be taken into consideration when trying to master these battles. High replayability. Its cliche story and unremarkable dialogue sequences are Clash of Heroes' only weak points, but these can be easily ignored for what it offers in return.

												My feelings towards Bejewled-inspired puzzle games has been lukewarm at best, even when the game is recognizably good or prettied up by Square-Enix. Not to say it's a bad basis for game design, just that it was one I didn't think was for me. But Clash of Heroes took me by surprise with an intelligent twist on the whole "Battle Bejewled" formula with a design that gives a lot of meaning and tension in your choices. Describing it is a bit hard, but once you get a hang of the basic idea, the game then adds a bunch of ways to maximize your damage if you're patient and have some foresight. Playing optimally takes work, and it's a lot of fun once all the different tools and variations are in play. The game also has a very modular design in pretty much every aspect: every unit has a different way to deal damage and a different timing on when they deal it, the items you equip and the spells you cast can have a significant affect on what your strategy will be going into the game. And on top of that, each army comes from six different races who all play very differently from each other.In short, this is a thoroughly excellent strategy game that delivers much more than anyone would have rightly expected from it. It's often on sale for $2.50, and a bargain at twice that price.

												A pretty simplistic game in appearance that reveals its complexity through a single hour of playtime.The basic 3-units principle(to make an attack, three vertical units of the same colour, to make walls, three horizontal) gets immensely complex and varied once you add links(having groups of the same colour attack at the same turn) that reinforce your attack, fusions(two attack groups one behind the other fuse into one group twice as strong), and of course Elite and Champion units that require 2 and 4 units to activate them.Almost every single unit from every single race has a specific capacity, poison, jumping over walls, magical defenses, immunity to attack while charging, hacking the enemy lines/enemy charging power while charging, the variety added to the basic 3-units system makes this an incredibly capable game with possibilities that never seem to be insufficient no matter the circumstances. You can literally be about to be killed by your enemy, call reinforcements, and find yourself gifted with a generous unit placement that allows you to build the walls and defenses you need to just survive and counterattack to victory. There is a freshness in this game that never dies out.It's actually one of its greatest strengths and weaknesses, how random the battles can go. You can be gifted with a perfect line of units from the very start or have absolutely nothing to go on with. The game can be very frustrating when a perfectly planned attack is ruined by the sudden arrival of an enemy Champion just in the column you're about to use to finish off your foe. It can also be frustrating in the other way: you will call reinforcements to see one of your costly Champion units die immediately at the hands of some basic enemy attack with 2 attack because you couldn't get it moving in time.As frustrating and unfair as the randomness is, it is also one of this game's best aspects. The only reason I speedrun this game is that it has the merit of never(apart from the tutorials) making me feel like déjà vu. Every battle is at least new enough, no moments in the game feel like I've been here before(except the bosses, of which there are only 4, along with quite a few unfair pre-prepared battles) and even when it does happen, the randomness of the reinforcements usually palliates that very quickly.Gameplay-wise, it's simply excellent. Having played through the campaign quite a few times for speedrunning, I have yet to find this game to bore me at any point, and it's quite surprising to realise how a simple system can be at the same time constantly demanding and very free.A good example is the fusions: if you want one, with core, Elite or Champion units, you're gonna have to get rid of all your walls first, since you need six tiles to make any fusion and there are only six between the goal your enemy has to hit and your first line.Beyond that, every hero has got his own superpower which can range from somewhat poor(hello Cyrus) to ridiculously broken when you know how to use them(hello Aidan with lots of walls, Anwen with a clear opening, Markal with two uncharged Death Knights).Beyond beyond that, artifacts can be found in many flavors in the campaign and then used profusely in skirmishes or online battles. And the variety there is by no means inferior to the one in the units, although I'm sure everyone will end up using ridiculously strong artifacts like the Spider Cloak, Lion's Mane or Celerity Ring.On a side note, the balancing of the campaigns is a bit poor. Why is Nadia not only ridiculously rich in HP(she starts at level 7 out of 10!), but also given enemies that play defensively, troops that make almost no damage, and is also generously dotted with Academy enemies, who can raise layers of superwalls like drinking a cup of coffee? It makes her campaign ridiculously long and just unpleasant. The times I get for Anwen range under 50 minutes, Godric takes less than an hour, Fiona has a rather long campaign that takes about 1h10 minutes, Aidan has a rather short campaign that also takes less than an hour, and Nadia ends up taking me 1 hour 40 minutes!Continuing on the bad side, the story is completely ignorable. It's not bad(no big plot holes, awful writing or terrible characters) but absolutely nothing about it feels in any way original. The characters almost feel stereotypical, you have the courageous and honorable big brother, the courageous but more sheltered little sister, the more angsty teenage younger brother, the huntress of the woods, the good student girl who fights the good fight...All of their personalities can be written in a quick line and although they never made me facepalm(none of the main five anyway), the last thing I wanted was to be tasked with finding an interesting personality trait among them. I don't mind finding needles in haystacks, but this is just impossible.The story is of the same type, it's nothing awful, but it doesn't convey anything even remotely amusing or deep. It ends in a happy note that works but doesn't really follow the somewhat tragic storytelling we had for most of the game. It's not really light on clichés and nothing about it is worth mentioning. I had a laugh once in the entire game. A giggle, really, at the demon who dies from the volcanic eruption he wanted to see. The rest is skippable. Special mention, though, to the villains: they range from comic relief(Azexes and his forgetful schoolboy behavior) to so obvious it hurts(Carlyle and his fashion for being a general ♥♥♥♥).Visually, I like the animé art style quite a lot, and the quality of the animations is certainly very helpful at making it a nice game to watch. I do have a serious issue about those: they're long. REALLY long. Sometimes it's ok, but seeing the knight twirl his spear around before charging for the 1000th time has really grown old. Less long animations would've really helped in making the game a lot more fun. The PLAYER TURN and ENEMY TURN screens are also ridiculous, they last something like 3,5 seconds! Talk about a needless loss of time! Those could've simply not existed and all would've been better. As much as I appreciate the animé visual style for almost everyone, some races are totally failed: the good guys and necromancers are mostly fine, but the magicians' golems or titans look nothing like the machines they are, although that's nothing in comparison to the Demons and how every unit but the hound is failed. Even when lit with flames and about to strike, I find it difficult to take the immense Pit Fiend more seriously than a plushie. Demons look neither scary nor ugly, and that's a true minus for me.With all that said, the last element is the music.It sucks.No other way to say it. This game has very poor music.Out of five campaigns, forests, a capital city of men, the land of the undead, Hell, and a mighty Magician tower, I remember exactly zero theme songs. Why? Because there aren't any songs. It's all ambients. BAD ambients, with no memorable sounds at all. Whooshing winds and shaking leaves, that's all. The battle musics are thankfully very varied, however that would be a good thing only if they didn't all suck as well! Out of the eight or so battle themes, there is one I like. The final boss music is fine too. The victory theme(the first 4 seconds of it anyway) and the two former are the only songs I can say I appreciate musically out of the whole game. Having played HoMM5 before, I know that many of these songs were taken from the rest of the franchise and sort of put in this one. It doesn't fit, none of the songs are that good, so it's a game that is terribly uninteresting musically.A lot more could be said about bad minigames, Sonic 06-type loading times(two loading times into each battle), but I reached the limit.Final word is that despite my complaints, this is an incredibly fun and varied game that always develops into more complexity and fun. Try it.
